reviewText: This was one of the best shows to ever be called "edge of your seat entertainment." That description was, at times, almost literal. Kiefer Sutherland was fantastic, clearly deserving of his Golden Globe win, and he was backed by a superb supporting cast. This was one show that I made it a point to go out of my way to watch every new episode. It hooked me from the start, and didn't let me go until the bang-up ending. And what an ending it was! "24" is a prime example of the type of quality programming television is capable of, if only the networks have the guts to take the risk.

I am totally hooked on 24 it is amazing. It isn't a straight forward good vs bad there are lots of sub plots, that keep you guessing on who the bad guy is in CTU. Kiefer Sutherland is excellent as Jack Baur he pulls the part off as if it were really happening to him, there is an amazing supporting cast as well. Although in the UK it is only dinner time, i challenge anyone to watch one episode and not get hooked. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD in the UK, as i will certainly be ordering it ASAP

I have seen all 24 hours worth of this series and I was blow away but how this series was pulled off. This is truely a very intense drama with Excellent plot twists.
I'm sure this DVD will be well worth it!

Pretty disapointing. The video is a compilation of two previously released documentaries. The first part is a rather crude "home movie" of the 100th mission flown by the 44th Bomb group. The film was shot not by official combat photographers but apparently by members of the group themselves,and assembled by the Group's Photo Officer. There is some narration by Col. Leon Johnson,who was with the Group at the time and had earlier won the Medal Of Honor for his part in the first Ploesti mission. Interesting for B-24 fans. The second,and longest,part of the video is an official Army Air forces film titled"Report From The Aleutians".Familiar to most World War Two video collectors,it depicts the activities of U.S. aviation on Adak. Filmed in Technicolor,this print is rather murky. B-24 footage is somewhat incidental,but there are good scenes of P-38 Lightning,P-39 Airacobra,and P-40 Warhawk operations as well. I can only reccomend this video if you are particularly interested in the subject matter.

The first few episodes were intriguing and enjoyable. However, it quickly went downhill as it became apparent that they were introducing and piling on one foolish event after another needlessly. To be honest, if it weren't for the wives and the children in the show it could have ended in less than half the length. But they dragged it out far too long pointlessly and ruined the show for me. I wanted to see the ending so skipped the last few episodes and most of the parts involving the wives and kids. That did not ruin the ending for me at all and I was quite happy with it since I had no sympathy for that character whatsoever. Maybe I am heartless, but I would argue it had more to do with the fact that that particular character was simply annoying and highly unrealistic.
It was pretty good up until the third episode in season one. I do not appreciate 2 women kissing so I quit!

I just finished watching season 1 of 8. It should have been 5.1 surround but it wasn't. I hope season 2 is 5.1. The picture is 16:9 so that compensates for the audio. The story is interesting. The action and violence is adequate. I watched six episodes today and the last four were after supper. I finished about twenty minutes before bedtime. Amazon Prime recommended this in an email one day and I will have seven more seasons at my disposal.
Love the series, but this DVD keeps stalling and blanking out.

I've heard so many rave reviews of this series that I decided to give it a try. The first few episodes were gripping, but when I figured out that the writers were going to drag out the plot for 24 episodes, I gave up. I need some kind of positive resolution to keep me watching when there are so many bad things happening at once. I kept going back to try, but eventually gave up. These stories would be fine for a movie, but dragging them out for so long forces the writers to introduce so many plot errors it detracts from the overall plot. Example: In Season 1, when the imposter father of Janet kills her, I wanted to scream, "NO NO NO! There's no way anyone could get away with smothering someone in intensive care who is hooked up to all those machines! That did it for me!

I watched the first 23 episodes of the TV series 24 and gave up half way through episode 24. Why you might ask?
This was a wildly popular show, starting in 2001, it ran through 2010, then came back in 2014 with another season and a spin off in 2017.
It won several awards for acting and even best dramatic series. So this must be a terrific show right? What's not to like?
Well, I can say the acting is top notch, the camera work and sets are well done. The format of a real time story line is fascinating and really draws you in.

Okay, the plot line is ridiculous. So much happens in 24 hours, so many rules are broken with no consequences, the bad guys have such pervasive information and connections, the star has endless energy.

I can accept all of that. What I can't accept is this.

Every female in the first season is a fool or a hypocrite or a traitor, a killer, a temptress, a manipulator or a heartless fiend of some sort.
It's too much. Why didn't anyone notice this? If you don't believe me, think about the characters in season one and what happened. Every woman is seriously flawed.

I can provide details if anyone is interested, but for this post I'm avoiding the spoilers in case anyone is like me and watching TV that's 16 years old for the first time.

In that case, my advice is to skip 24.
Cool!
Thank you.

The best thing about reviewing '24' is that you only need to review one season. Literally, every season is exactly the same.

Corrupt President? Check.
Bad guy inside CTU? Check.
Imminent danger to the Country? Check.

Every season is exactly the same. Entertaining? Absolutely. Original? Don't bet on it. It's a miracle it went on for 8 seasons. I recommend it.

Video quality is great, 1.78.1 Anamorphic. Special features are worth watching also. The ONLY bad thing is that I'm giving Fox money to fund their State-Run Media Network, Fox News.

I should also mention that every now and then, they insert 'conservative' ideas/comments. Thankfully it's usually a one-liner or Fox News playing on the TV. It's also funny they have a version of "CNN" that is only watched by Terrorists and bad guys. I had to roll my eyes at that one as I'm not easily fooled by brainwashing. Seriously, watch for it.

To end -- buy it, watch it, enjoy it.

I decided to try watching 24, because I never watched it when it originally aired.  Initially, the main storyline of the show was good enough to hold my interest despite the annoying side storielines.  Half way through I realized I no longer cared for these characters.  They make many stupid decisions and get entangled in uninteresting side drama.  The agents show how incompetent they are in multiple scenarios.  I tried sticking it out, but eventually, I stopped watching.  Perhaps this show was the first of its kind, but tv shows have advanced quite a bit since then.

Well lets see: everyone knows 'anyone' can walk around a crime scene; be told the facts of an investigation and walk around freely in an highly secure facility right?!
  Oh.....that bullet proof car....can simply be accessed with a baseball bat or the butt of an rifle???????????
The agents.... a few have nothing to do but watch each other - I guess that is the way it is at Homeland Security and other anti-crime units.
  Didn't Palmers Wife remind you of someone??? (Hilary)?

I could go on but It has occurred to me - there are over 9,000 very bored people out there with not much in their lives.

The repetitive hero tropes in this show are unbearable (decent locations and action sequences raised the 1-star to 2-stars).

If you care that women are positively portrayed in TV shows, don't watch this show.  The "wife" and "daughter" only exist as plot objects to be vulnerable, protected and rescued, over and over. Therefore, they repeatedly endanger themselves so the hero has more opportunities to be heroic.
Furthermore, the Presidential candidate is a plot object that exists only to provide a target for the Villains.
Casting him as a black Senator perhaps makes him more vulnerable to be protected by the Caucasian hero?

It's embarrassing that white guys were still writing this dreck in 2002.

The storyline comes straight out of an online writer's handbook.
Really. Google this: "Villains Act, Heroes React"  tvtropes.org
It completely describes this TV show.  Compare these two plot excerpts to the handbook  excerpts after them.

====  The Plot
Villains have a plan to kill the first black US Presidential Candidate. They kidnap the wife+daughter (W+D) of US Counter Terrorism Agent Jack Bauer to force him to assassinate the Senator.  Jack's reaction is that he is the only person who can thwart their attack and rescue his wife+daughter (W+D).  Meanwhile, Jamie, the steely single-mother Latina, and computer network expert is revealed to be a traitor. However, once she's caught. She summarily kills herself with a coffee mug.  Jack finally triumphs in saving the Senator, killing the main Villain and rescuing his family.
Then, duty once again calls him away from his family.

Villains invoke plan B to kill Senator. W+D are kidnapped again. Almost every subvillain is killed by Jack's own team so Jack must then become even more heroic to rescue his family and capture the masterminds behind the assassination plot.

Fellow agent Nina, the sultry slender brunette provides steadfast support of Jack's heroics. This substantiates her (anticipated) future reveal as a double agent.

==== The Handbook excerpts
"Villains Act, Heroes React
If somebody has a plan at the start of the story, that character is probably a villain....Most heroes are protectors of some kind (cops, doctors (in medical dramas), or the parents of children who are being threatened by some (possibly supernatural) evil),

Vasquez Always Dies
When two Action Girls are featured in the same film, frequently the tougher, more aggressive and less feminine character will die, despite being better equipped for the situation at hand...One of the reasons is the belief that the femininity and sex appeal of a female character determines their usefulness as Love Interest or Fanservice or, in the most insulting cases, their reason to be in the story at all...  It's easier for an audience to feel fear if the Final Girl is less battle savvy and thus more vulnerable - a hardened Vasquez left alone wouldn't be as terrifying....
Writers will sometimes compensate by making the more attractive woman some sort of mysterious secret agent..."

Season one started off fine... then more and more... and more violence. Season 2 is even worse. Deteriorated to 3 ... maybe 2 stars. Jury's out. I enjoyed Blue Blood-- which also got more violent as the seasons wore on, but there was a balance of the show always pointing back to a conscientious commitment to explore the dark side through the lens of "The Sunday Dinner." This show, 24, makes no such effort. And it seems to me it's just one more show that is deadening our population to moral and ethical atrocities that were not a part of everyday living 30 years ago. As we began to see the rise in violence on television in the early 1980's, we started down a slippery and dangerous slope. I wish that 24 would have found another way to create an "on the edge of one's seat" suspense without the ceaseless violence.

Watched the first 17 episodes, finally gave up in disgust for having watched the plot drawn out for so long. Jack Bauer calls it the longest day of his life...I can relate watching the first season, seems like the longest day of my life too! Does no one not get tired after being up for 2 days and 1 night? All of the character's persona created by the writers, are just not believable. One man out to save the word with the aid of a few flunkies who sit in the office and answer Jack's phone calls? How many times can Jack keep asking his wife and daughter if they are ok? Enough already! Can Jack's wife and daughter get a better script? The daughter goes over the edge of a steep canyon and emerges with her full faculties, but the mom just faints and gets amnesia as a result? really? I found the series "Black List" to far more entertaining than this soap opera charade.

I am not a tv watcher, per se. I generally am disdainful of people who like tv shows. But this blows me away. This is the best, smartest, most innovative action/intrigue show I have ever seen. It has covert-agent action-intrigue, national-level political intrigue, office politics, family politics, intense action (not crappy "tv" quality at all! But motion picture quality), taut, intense drama, and  astounding twists. A season is 24 hour-long episodes. The 24 episodes represent 24 hours in a day. So, a season is events that happen in a day. It works because it gives tbe writers astounding room to flesh out the intimate aspects of a story. In most other tv shows, things are resolved in an hour. This takes 24 hours. We have been binge-watching and are half way through season 2. And, going back for more tonight.

The series is well-acted, filmed well, and has constant tense action.  It's only real failing is the writing--the story is entirely too dependent on characters making stupid decisions that place them in danger.  The hero tells someone to stay just where they are, and of course they get up and leave.  Or, instead of escaping to a busy street where they can ask for help, they instead run down a blind alley.  These plot devices are annoying, and they are so frequent it spoils the flow of the show.  We keep watching, because the story and acting are rather addictive, but we can't watch more than two or three episodes at a time without become antsy because of the stupid plot twists.  For lack of anything better, we have started watching season 2, and already the stupid decisions are proliferating.

I have heard many positive things about the show when it was on the air, but I never got around to watching it.  When I recently discovered that I could watch it for free as part of the Prime membership, I thought I'd give it a try.
Maybe it's that I'm watching it 15 years after it aired.  Maybe it's that it uses editing and technology that have long since been used in other shows and surpassed.  But I just couldn't stick with it for a long run.  I got to the second season, which felt like a chore at times.  I fell asleep during one of the episodes (don't remember which one), and never bothered picking it back up.
There are too many contrivances for my taste, and too much "show for show's sake", in my opinion.  And I really do *not* like all the political scheming and back-stabbing, not just among the politicians, but among all the characters.  In the first season and change, no character seemed to like any other character, and they only worked together because some circumstance forced them to.  While situations like this may be true in Hollywood, they are not the case everywhere else.

We all have seen wardrobe/hairstyle changes, etc. in one frame to the next, or a microphone hanging into the top of the picture.  To call attention to it, is small-minded and means someone doesn't have enough productive things to do.

My husband and I were really enjoying 24. We started with Season 1 Episode 1. We were enjoying the story, the acting and the excitement until we had watched two thirds of Season 1. It was then that the politics of  the screen writers for this series became evident. The series was enjoyable until they decided to make the good guys and the Presidential Candidate - Democrats. Well now you have ruined it for us. We no longer look forward to watching because we now know this series is an attempt by the left wing, big money, political machine to indoctrinate us and force their views on us. We will never know how any of the issues were resolved because we now are finished watching . We will not be watching this political fairy tale anymore. It's too bad that we can't enjoy television without having a political agenda imposed upon us.

"24" is a fantasy built on a misconception born of the great lie to explain why the Bush Administration resorted to torture in dealing with terrorism.  The great lie was, and is, that torturing a suspect to get information about an imminent terrorist threat will produce reliable information.  Having been close to the intelligence community, I know for certain that it doesn't work that way, never did and never will. However, having said that, it's also fair to say that "24" is a well-produced entertainment even though it over-indulges plausibility. It takes some real-world events and fantasizes about "what-ifs".

60% of the scenes could have been cut and it would have been more enjoyable. There were so many errors in continuity that it was distracting.
For example, when the daughter is in the barn she has brown sandals on, a few moments later she has on pink loafers. Then back to brown sandals in the next scene. The size of the burn on her hand depends on who was doing make up that day. Changes frequently. Some people get killed. It is amazing that no one got any blood on them when they hid the blood soaked body. In the helicopter the wig on one of the characters is not only fake looking, it is also the wrong color. I can't believe that this and many more mistakes got by the editors.

My best friend told me to watch this series years ago but I never seemed to find the time.  This past week I've been down with a severe sinus attack so it seemed a good time to check out "24".  WOW!!  Non-stop action and intrigue, just the way I like it.  I'm not a big fan of gratuitous violence and many so-called intrigue shows have a lot of that but "24" doesn't.  Oh, it has its share of violence, some of which was new to me, but at least it made sense to the story.  I admit I was a tad perturbed at some of the stupid choices a few of the characters made that put them in harms way, but it's easy to armchair those situations. Ditto the fact that there's a lot of rogue activity in the agency which immediately puts a business owner on edge because of the gaps in protocol, but overall, it's a great series.  I've watched 54 episodes already and unless they get too political, I'll probably go the distance with this one.  (It's a pet peeve of mine when producers rewrite history to suit their programming.) I must say, before this series the only exposure I had to Kiefer Sutherland was his character in "A Few Good Men".  He's terrific in this series, as are the other regs. Lots of great action and good storylines!

How refreshing to see some action drama that is not overly concerned about being politically correct.  Our feature character, Jack Bauer, is an incredibly resourceful and dedicated government agent (CTU).  This series is wonderfully cast with Jack, members of CTU, President Palmer and his wife.  I thought that Penny Johnson Jerald was spectacular and was so convincing as the highly motivated politician's wife.
  The series are one hour snippets within one day - they pack in more action in one hour than I have all day long and that is how I like it.
  I recommend - I think you will enjoy!

This show started out great, like the beginning to "The Wire." I found the plot intricate, and riveting, and would watch several episodes back-to-back.
However, by the end of the first season, I became disappointed, because character twists and flawed writing left me saying, "that's just not possible, given what has happened earlier in the season." It left such a bad taste in my mouth that I am not sure I will spend the time (1,008 minutes, at 24 episodes x 42 minutes per) to watch season two.

All dramatic movies and television shows require what is called "suspension of disbelief," that is, that something improbable could actually be possible. But the twists late in this season went beyond my capacity to suspend disbelief, and I wound up feeling cheated. Still, four stars for a very interesting, novel concept, with good acting, and good writing until near the end. Perhaps they should have hired me on as a consultant to rein them in a little at the end...

I enjoyed the premise, delivery and execution of most of the plot lines, but I had serious issues with the Bauer ladies character choices and decisions, which carried enough weight for two stars IMO.

For example (some mild plot spoiler incoming) in one scene as the ladies are making an escape in a motor vehicle, they think they lost the pursuer by turning off the main road, onto a small dirt road. They come to a stop and the mother gets out of the vehicle to check if they lost the pursuers, setting up the next plot development.

She. Gets. Out. Of. The. Vehicle.
Seriously! If there was a contest of worst decisions made by tv characters in all of time, this one would be the defending champion for eternity.

I don't know if it was intentional, but in general it seems that all ladies of the show were designed to be mind numbingly stupid. It hurt my head. I realize this was kinda the way they were portrayed 15 years ago, but it was really bad writing and I can't believe some of it actually aired.

All I ever heard from people was how this show was so awesome.  I guess I missed the boat on this one.  I tried watching the first season, and I kept telling myself that it must get better, but after episode 17 I had to give up.  The characters did nothing, except make one stupid decision after another just for the sake of trying to keep the plot going.  The show is full of bad actors which I'm sure get killed off within the first few seasons, but it wasn't soon enough for me.  Jack's wife, Teri was the worst of the bunch.  Plenty of fake crying, but not one tear to be seen.  The lack of realism in the show is what completely ruined it for me.  The only thing that got me to the 17th episode was how funny and unbelievable things got.  I never liked soap operas, but this was a soap opera which was made for prime time.  After the wife got *Spoiler Alert* amnesia, that was the final straw.  Jack kept saying at the beginning of the episode that this was the longest day of his life...well...me too, buddy...me too.

A timeless cutting edge TV drama. At the time of broadcast, the episodes were shown in "real time" ie, if your clock showed 9:15 at a commercial break, the shows time clock would current hour:15 & if it returned at say 9:19, the show clock would also reflect current hour:19. To my knowledge, no other regular TV show before or since has ever tried that. Throw in a lot of action, great writers and a stellar cast led by Keifer Sutherland and you have a classic! I loved it then and I would still watch it today. LOVE this show but be warned, it is as addictive as crack cocaine and once your hooked, it will be very hard to walk away.

When 24 hit the small screen it was a new and interesting method of thriller storytelling as events were in "real time." This innovative way of telling a story was rarely, if ever attempted in film or TV.
The nailbiting scenarios presented in 24 were nothing short of hair raising. For many viewers, the question to contemplate was; could these events really be occurring secretly in society? Were the scenarios featured be taken from actual clandestine operations undertaken by US counterinsurgency agencies? Thrilling, harrowing, and we'll acted gives 24's first season top marks for originality and suspense.

The overall acting is really good, the inconsistency in the daughter and the mother's personality and acting really bothers me though.  It's like she went from being an angsty rebellious teenager to being a very calm, problem-solving oriented analytical/manipulative person, to being a very soft incapable whiny girl to once again being an angsty rebellious teenager - didn't currently finish the whole season but I wanted to get that off my back.  The mom's acting is also very.... okay I guess but I hate the inconsistencies in her character as well.  She goes from being super needy and incapable to being the tough mom who's holding it all together to then being like vindictive and irritable - which I mean I guess you can blame that a little bit on the reveal (don't want to put any spoilers).  Given that this occurred within less than a day, because this show supposedly shows what happens in real time, it seems odd that there are such crazy shifts in character between these two people.  Everyone else's acting also appears on point, at least for the most part, but these two specific characters, im not sure if its the writing for them or the acting but it kinda throws me off everytime their in a scene.  Despite this, pretty good plotline but its too many left-turns and right-turns where something also happens but doesn't quite happen and things get messed up or plans have to change every hour or less than that.  It's a sort of "unpredictability" that essentially becomes a little bit predictable, which I don't necessarily like in my movies - kinda like when you watch a horror story and you know theres gonna be a jump scare within the next 5 seconds of something happening and you're like goddamit why did i have to be right..  its like the story only advances because people are unreasonable and brash where they shouldn't be and it stays on point or a certain plotline because people are reasonable and make smart decisions momentarily, before some kinda of sneaky, brash, oversight/undersight happens to advance the story.  It's a very good story and the time ticking down after each episode is a good cliffhanger and made me want to watch more despite the above mentioned.

Interesting approach - unusual story.  I missed the series when it first came out - but it was highly recommended.  I found myself questioning many times why this was supposed to be worth while.  I still wonder whether 180 turns are genius by the writers or just stupid tricks (like a revelation that the prior scenes were dreams - and not real) - but I am leaning toward the latter.  I am hoping that the person recommending this series was right - just recommending something later than Season 1.

We started series 1 and in five episodes we saw chopped up dead bodies, watched adults having sex, saw scantily dressed teenagers having sex (whose parents wonder why their child would be in that situation), saw homicide after homicide, and watched nothing but dark, dark non-entertainment. Very little engaging dialogue and lots of racing around from one murder scene to another, where almost all the "good guys" (FBI) are evil. I'm sick and tired of calling evil, good, and calling good, evil. Nearly every single TV series available today is based off this dark and miserable "entertainment", leaving one empty and sickened about the state of the Hollywood fare being offered. No wonder our children are depressed, committing suicide, or trying to escape on drugs. Everything they see is about that. How about some genuine entertainment for a change?

Anyone that would binge watch this entire season in one week-end (as one reviewer did) explains why the world is in such a mess. You'll be brain dead after that experience!  Got a recommendation from a highly respected family member, bought season one and lasted two hours (two episodes!). I was done when the girl blew herself out of the plane.  WHA..? Maybe the craziness was intentional - as in, this would never happen, we're just throwing it all at you!  Blam blam blam. Dialogue was puny, a lot of one word responses from irritable people looking around suspiciously. A lot of people doing seriously stupid things. I must join in with many other reviewers and say "what in the world was so good about this show?"  :-p  So I've panned it and am free to do so, but you don't have to take my word for it.  You can easily form your own opinion... which is what this forum is all about.  Sharing opinions.  Period.

Did only Season 1 stink??? My latest binge watch....a testament to my addiction to staying up all night watching ANYTHING.  I have just made it through the first season and may just skip to the last to see if it improved over its 10 year run.  Maybe that would explain its popularity and awards. After cutting cable, I have streamed most of the best, A-list series, like Sopranos, Breaking Bad, Damages, etc. Now I am exploring B-list candidates hoping for a winner. This is not it. The concept was cool .That's where the positive comments end. The acting is hilariously bad.  I don't know if the casting call was for "emotionally stunted types" or the director was going for a thriller-spoof. Kiefer (even his name starts me giggling) Sutherland as a counter-terrorist Jack Bauer, reminds me of a hamster with a bad bleach job. They forgot, however, to give his wife, Leslie Hope, a bleach job...on her teeth. Really, it's distracting. Usually such brown teeth are reserved for old English movies. It is bitchily fun to do a "Joan Rivers" on the actors' looks mostly because criticizing this awful mess is the only entertainment I get from watching it. The finale left me gasping....with laughter. I suspect the writers got stoned or drunk, wrote this as a satire, and discovered they had a hit drama from the viewing public who loves daytime soaps.

Season 1 of 24 stars Kiefer Sutherland as Jack Bauer. Jack Bauer works in the Counter Terrorist Unit (CTU) based out of Los Angeles California. He puts his all into his job and ends up juggling the demands of protecting  Senator David Palmer and his family from being assassinated (Senator David Palmer is played by Dennis Haysbert also known as the Allstate Insurance guy) and looking after his daughter  Kim.  Kim ran away when Jack Bauer and his wife Teri were about to talk to Kimberly about a personal family issue. Things get even more complicated when Jack Bauer learns that there is a mole within his own agency and his daughter Kim and her friend Janet have been kidnapped.  Of course, there is so much more to 24 than what I just listed an Season 1 of the 24 series definitely keeps a person in suspense.  There is even information online about certain key addresses such as for  2350 Dunlop Plaza in Los Angeles California to be an office building location for the hour sequence of 1-2 am in the 24 tv series of season 1 (listed via online wikia).

UPDATED:
What I wrote below still holds but after sticking through the full first season I had to downgrade this. The plot holes are so glaring we just couldn't keep ignoring them, even after really really trying.  Not worth our time, we're moving on to different shows.

The show has lots of action and suspense but the plot is ridiculous if you think about it at all. The villains' schemes are so overly and needlessly complicated that it reminds me of the old Batman TV series. SPOILER ALERT FIRST TWO EPISODES - for example, to get an assassin into a breakfast banquet to kill a presidential candidate the terrorists put someone on a plane next to a journalist, steal his id on the plane, parachute out over the desert while blowing up the plane, put the id in a case with a homing device and bury it in the desert where it is later picked up by someone who delivers it to the assassin who has just spent several months having plastic surgery so that he looks like the journalist, and hack into the airline's computer system to erase the record of the real journalist being on the plane. Really? With all that time, effort, risk and money they couldn't just forge a press pass? Or how about just shoot the guy while he's wandering around outside his hotel with minimal security?

'24' is by far one of the best, if not THE best, shows that my wife & I have ever had the privilege of watching when it comes to pure, high adrenaline entertainment!! From the start to the finish of each episode this show offers nothing short of the biggest "bang for your buck".....and I mean that quite literally! Kiefer Sutherland plays the role of Jack Bauer (he works for the CTU.....Counter Terrorist Unit) so well that it's nothing short of amazing. It's as if he was "born" to play this role. It's the type of role for someone like himself, Tom Cruise or Matt Damon to play and not too many others could pull it off the way that Kiefer S. does in this exciting, hang onto your seat type of action series. Each season is all about what happens in any given 24 hour period.....one full day......24 shows @ 1 hour each = 24 hours......thus the title '24'. If you like shows involving lots of action with great story lines....then this show is definitely for you! Enjoy!!

Innovative for its time because of the unique concept of having an entire season of a television series comprise one day, with each episode taking place within an hour of that day, 24 hits the ground running and never lets up until the final seconds. Incredibly well written and spectacularly acted, this television series has twists and turns that will keep you guessing.

I highly recommend it. Includes an alternate ending with and without commentary from co-creator and co-executive producer Joel Surnow, and an introduction to Season One by Kiefer Sutherland.

I binged on Amazon Prime. "24" is intense, mesmerizing, habit forming. I watched the first episodes when the series first appeared and dropped it when the candidate for President who was married and the father of two presented himself as a trustworthy, moral man but was  edging close to having an affair with an aide. Hypocrite politician, nothing new there. Or so I thought. My recent binge watching revealed the writers are smarter than that. In fact they are masters in presenting surprising plot twists and getting into the minds of even the worst criminals letting the viewer delve into questions of good and evil while Jack Bauer keeps us on the edge of out seat wondering how he will get out of his latest predicament.

Action-packed thriller, cleverly conceived and expertly written. However, there are a few logical gaps, but they do not detract from the action-packed story line, which is full of twists and turns. With a few exceptions, the acting is terrific. Photography, make-up, and lighting are superb. And, behind the raw, gut-wrenching drama, the thoughtful viewer can draw some philosophical conclusions of how this series mirrors what's sad in contemporary USA society where virtuous men and women with uncompromising courage are so rare they almost always must stand alone fighting Herculean battles against the forces of corruption and moral decay.

The script, performances, and cultural settings are much lower quality  than  I expected, based on the hype.  This series is clearly not on par with other good and gritty series, such as Deadwood, Justified, Boardwalk Empire, The Americans, Transparent, Homeland, The Wire, Blacklist, Orange is the New Black, The Good Wife, The Sopranos, etc. I would recommend any/all of the above rather than '24'.  Having said that, I am nevertheless hooked into Season 2, and will likely play  it through to the end -- as I await  the next seasons of better options and tend to other tasks (knitting, ironing, etc.).

[Of course, Game of Thrones and House of Cards are on a quality level all their own.]

Over the years I have heard so many talk this show up so very much but had never seen one episode. I would see portions of shows in announcements for marathon sessions for when I finally with nothing to do while away on work I finally started this season one. I would say that I began to see what others had spoken of because I was almost addicted to finish the season and the drama and could not wait for the time to watch the next episode. I loved the drama and the cliff hanging way the shows would end as the teased ever so provocatively the next chapter in the show. I do believe that I am glad that I did not watch this in real time as I would probably have pulled my hair out waiting a week instead of only a few hours or a day. But I must say that I have NEVER seen a conclusion that I hated more. I was sick to see it end the way that it did and am not inclined to pick up another season if this is the pattern going forward.

Didn't watch it during it's original release. I don't think it holds up very well, story seems very drawn out, lacks suspense, and A few of the characters(i.e. both the wives) are inconveniences that you have to ignore to enjoy the show. You never grow to dislike the bad guy because he changes every few episodes, and ultimately ends with a terribly unbelievable accent. Plot "twists" are seen a mile away, mostly to fall flat. As a pilot season I'm willing to forgive some of these errors, but the following seasons will have some work to do to win me over.

So you have no idea of what is going to happen from the cliff hanger first episode until 24 hours episodes later.  That is just too frustrating for me.  This first season has a shocking ending that frankly was upsetting to me.  You do get vested in certain characters and seeing them go through hell for 23 episodes and then die - is not fun for me at all.  The writers are definitely going for shock value but it really turned me off.

OK, admittedly I am a bit cynical since I used to work in this field to an extent. And while any show should be granted a certain theatrical license to make a topic more interesting and exciting, the plot to "24" was so convoluted, its action sequences so absurd, its antagonists so cartoonish that I I could not bring myself to grant it the suspension of disbelief often required of television and movie.

All thriller genre shows make things more exciting than they are in reality and given the premise of the show, an hour of exciting tv for each hour in the fictional day of Agent Jack Bauer, perhaps it was unavoidable that the action sequences bordered on the absurd. So maybe I expected too much from the show and was as a result so thoroughly disappointed. I even found myself angry at the show at times for how bad the writing was. That all being said, I did watch it in its entirety even if it was largely because I was morbidly curious. But I can assure you I won't be watching the following seasons.

I have mixed feelings and impressions about this series. It is certainly packed with action--it really stimulates the flow of adrenalin. On the other hand, the action overtakes the character development to a certain extent. Everything moves so fast that it is hard to really become involved with any one person. In my opinion, it is certainly not the caliber of "The Wire" or "Oz." All of that being said, I have just started watching Season 2. Perhaps it is the kind of show that takes time to allow the viewer to become invested in the characters.

I have often considered giving this series a try given that it was so popular and was on the air for nine seasons. As I write this review we are more than half way through Season One and find it increasingly difficult to stick with it. The plot lines are becoming more and more unbelievable, the acting is terrible, and I can't believe the apparent lack of any technical advisors.  We have decided to try and finish this season and start the next one in hopes that they hired new writers and the acting improves. If Season Two is not significantly better within a few episodes we will consider it a failed experiment.  Be warned...Season One REALLY sucks.

We started watching this fresh on the heels of Justified (with Timothy Oliphant). Suffice it to say, the acting on Season 1 was so bad (ESP in comparison to Justified) that there were times hubby and I were laughing our a**es off at Season 1. The women in this season are totally lame and helpless (not to mention all have really ugly haircuts...??!!) and can't seem to make the correct decision EVER. And every government agent aside from Jack Bauer is totally, incomprehensibly, incompetent. The plot points are very predictable and I drove hubby nuts calling out what would happen before it happened - I know, totally annoying but I couldn't help myself. And I have no idea how Keifer Sutherland managed to sound like a South Park parody of himself every time he said what hours the episodes took place between (seriously, he was channeling Trey Parker).

ANYWAY - with all of that being said, by the time we made it to Season 3 (OMG, literally three days of my life I can never get back), hubby and I had kinda' fallen in love with Jack Bauer and his amazing shite-kicking abilities. It is because of this that I must, out of respect, give Season 1 its due respect.

So, if you're on the fence, and have several days of free time waiting to be spent, this is totally worth it.

Sorry to all of you 24 fans.  First of all, I love the concept - nothing else like it on TV and for that reason alone it should be watched.  But the writing .. oh my goodness.  First of all, the bad decision made by characters in this show that put them knee deep in trouble - it reminds me of that commercial where the teenagers are at haunted house and instead of getting into the running car they go hide behind a row of chainsaws - and the chainsaw massacre guy is just shaking his head ("Really?") .. It's like every bad decision that a person in trouble could make to get deeper into trouble is made by these characters.  I found myself sitting there in agony watching it.  How could they be so stupid???

And, remember, this all takes place in one 24 hour period, the number of times things happen at exactly the last second to completely change the direction of events - unbelievable - truly NOT believable.  Just as a person is about to push a button, or shoot someone, or be found out, or whatever - just at that last second - something happens to save the day or change the course.  It's ridiculous at times.

In hour 23, Teri Bauer says, "When is this going to end?" and I laughed saying to myself - I agree!  When??

All that said, watch it if just for the concept which is killer by the way.  Ok I'm going to hit the submit button ... unless something happens at the last second to stop me!

These people must have predicted streaming and smart TVs.  The format with each episode being another hour of the same day and the way it follows separate threads keeps the action going. It makes you want to watch the next episode right away. Perfect for binge watching - I love how the Fire stick goes automatically to the next episode.
With that said it isn't a perfect show by any means. The story thins out as you advance through the day and they keep resurrecting it with the typical tricks of any TV series. At one point you start to wonder how many agents are you willing to let die to save a couple of people who don't even like you. Anyway, the shortcomings aside, it is an addictive show if you like action.

Just like Pringles, or Ruffles, whatever - you can't have just one.  There have been some seriously sleepless nights in our house since we started watching.  And I almost feel like binge-watching 24 episodes is achievement :)  But I am so glad that I waited to watch this on Amazon Prime, because there is no way I would have lived through a season having to wait a week between episodes!  I am even more happy that I am not part of Jack Bauer's family!

The show is absolutely incredible.  It runs in real time, so each episode takes one hour, with each thread of action happening concurrently.  Starting off with Jack and his family in the living room, it quickly goes from there to kidnapping, espionage, and an attempt to thwart an assassination on the black candidate for president, played by Dennis Haysbert.  I WISH this president could actually run, interesting dynamic to see his incredibly strong integrity in tension with those around him and how that impacts the overall story.

Sutherland is the perfect star for this show - family guy, not the standard tough guy, but smart and resourceful.  He is a very well-balanced character.  This is truly the longest day of his life, and you get to share it every step of the way with him.  There are a few really key surprises that will shock you.

I have found only a few small mistakes throughout, sometimes something gets misplaced slightly, etc., but not something that bothers you unless you are an editor for a living.

Watch this show, but be warned, it is incredibly addictive, and with so many seasons, you and your family will need to accommodate!

I'm giving this popular, well regarded series just a #3, though the directing, acting and sophisticated plot (and the multiple subplots) would seem to qualify it for a #4 or #5.  As other reviewers have noted, the series is indeed suspenseful and fast paced.  However, it is just too violent.  Brutally violent scenes occurred throughout the episodes, interrupted every so often with non-violent conversations between certain characters.  But, even the non-violent segments were filled with stress, quarrels and angry accusations.  I watched the first 5 CDs, and the beginning of the 6th CD, before finally deciding to give up.  I can't reveal the nature of the violent episodes as examples without being a spoiler.  So in short, the episodes are gritty, very dark, relentlessly tense and stressful, with a great deal of portrayed anguish and bloodshed.  Could we say that this is art imitating life?  Was this what the events following the JFK assassination were like, with multiple murders, mysterious deaths of people who knew too much, and a massive coverup?  I certainly wouldn't recommend this for youngsters.

I did not see this the first time it was on TV, why I don't really remember. I do remember people raving about how great it was. I was skeptical. I like Keifer Sutherland, but I couldn't picture this guy with a sort of baby face and a cute little turned up nose as a tough spy guy. Sort of like, No way! Well, I now guess Keifer is a pretty good actor because he makes me forget how cute he is and I can totally buy him as a tough guy. And then there is the program format. The show is 24 because each episode is an hour in a 24 hour day in Jack Bauer's life. The show moves along at a very brisk pace with two or three storylines going at the same time. Sort of like real life does. It never slows down or gets boring. I do very much enjoy it. Five stars for acting and storytelling.

I never watched this series when it first aired, but picked up on it after all eight seasons were over on Netflix.  This was the season that started it all, and started a revolution.  The ticking clock and real-time storyline is very unique and works to perfection.  Jack Bauer is a character that is simply unforgettable. His ability to get the job done no matter what the cost makes me like him even more.  The characters are developed enough, though the story revolves around the action and not so much those characters.  David and Sherry Palmer are well acted, as are Tony Almeida, Nina Myers, and some of the other memorable characters from this first season.

Jack Bauer gets contacted to try and stop an assassination of a U.S. Senator who is running for president.  His wife and daughter are kidnapped, and he must cooperate with the kidnappers or they will die.  He is trying to stop an assassination and get his family back at the same time.  There are moles, betrayals, and drama around every turn.  There are 24 episodes in each season that represent each hour of the day the story takes place.  I was so happy to have watched it on Netflix, where I could binge watch it and not have to wait.  I don't think I would have been able to wait so long to find out what happened next.  The season starts a bit slow, but ends with a shocker of a season finale.

Once you watch this season, you will be hooked and want more 24.

I have watched all seasons available for the series '24'. I consider this one of the better series available. It is action packed, and  while this is unfortunate I do believe it presents a pretty realistic perspective on how 'things' are with our government agencies. The concerns are more about 'who is doing what', 'how can I bring positive attention to what I am doing', rather than about 'minding ones own business' and essentially just doing a good job. The action/drama is very good. I wish there were more seasons of 24 coming down the pike!

This show has the usual TV series flaws in which the writers over create drama by having characters do obviously stupid things.  Just as in a low budget horror film, Jack is left alone in a field when we know that terrorist assassins were spending gobs of money to have the power grid shut off in that area.  The viewer can expect an overwhelming military operation to be taking place there but some our counter terrorist expert characters think are skeptical.  I still give it five stars compared to all the lame alternatives.

Was just scrolling through Amazon Instant Video trying to find a T.V. show to watch. For whatever reason, this caught my eye and I decided to give it a shot. I'm glad I did. Now I don't watch T.V. as much as other people do, and I find it pretty hard to get hooked on a show, or in other words, a show that is so addictive that it makes me want to keep watching and watching to see how the story unravels. From the first episode, you're left wanting to know more. There's plot twists everywhere imaginable, and any "dull" moments are quickly dispatched as action can come at the most unexpected moments.

As far as the actors, they're all great. I especially have admired the role that Kiefer Sutherland plays. Over the course of the first season I have grown attached to the gritty, no-nonsense, cunning character that Jack is. He goes to the limit to protect those he cares about most.

All in all, give this show a shot. I found it very hard to watch just one episode at a time. Hours of sleep were definitely lost over this first season, and I look forward to losing a lot more as I watch the rest in time.

A *very* good series.  Grips you from the opening scene all the way through the end - and you can't wait for the following season.  Great characters, very well developed.  A decent amount of action.  However...
What's the deal with all the women???  *MOST* of them (with a very few exceptions) are spies, assassins, traitors, plotters, liars, etc.  In retrospect (and it applies to all the following seasons) - all the most deadly and elaborate conspiracies that one could not have even imagined are done by women and through women (or their connections with the male characters).  If it's not a spoiler for the entire series:  just watch closely  :)
But most importantly:  ENJOY!
P.S.  The missing fifth star in my review is in the headline...  Otherwise, this series deserves a full five rating.

24 Season 1 introduced us to Jack Bauer and CTU (Counter Terrorism Unit) and television hasn't been the same since. Jack Bauer is the ultimate American hero who makes James Bond look like a lightweight. From now on all secret agents will be compared to Bauer and all crime fighting organizations will be compared to CTU.

24 Season 1 give the audience an idea of the evil and treachery in the world and how Jack Bauer can't punch out at 5 o'clock and leave the problems at the office. They follow him everywhere; even home. If you haven't seen 24 Season 1 you are truly missing out.

Got through 4 episodes hoping it would get better only to find that it got worse.  This show gives off the bad kind of suspense that involves a whole lot of absurd coincidences and cheesy, unbelievable moments.  Those kind of moments where you are cringing in your seat.  The problem is that they insert those moments every 5 seconds until you are just pissed off that so many coincidences in one day is an un-quantifiable number for odds.  EVERY main character story line on the show seems to suffer from this same fate.  In three hours time these individuals faced more action than most Navy Seals face in a lifetime (Slightly sarcastic here but not by much).  So much unreal and unbelievable situations here but the problem is that they are trying to be 100 percent serious about it.  I really tried to like it given the ratings but that bad script writing that plagued the 90s/early 2000s, before the industry realized that people like believable situations, is completely apparent here.  I was completely misled about the quality of this show.  Oh and one last thing; all side characters on this show seem to be completely unbelievable idiots, jerks, or cannon fodder.  For example, all police officers on this show have the brain and attention span of a hamster and need constant guidance by the "expert" main characters.  That is just one example of many lame side character types on this show.

When this series first ran on TV I was interested in seeing it, however I detest trying to enjoy a TV show when it is interrupted every seven minutes with another seven minutes of commercials, so I passed it up.  Now that it is available  on Amazon Prime without interruptions, I gave it a try and was overwhelmed!
Without the ususal interruptions, the story races through at an amazing speed.  The writing, casting and acting are superb.  Multiple characters have their own problems, along with the main anti-criminal theme -- and as soon as you begin rooting for a certain character, that person suddenly turn out to be a bad guy. . . and as soon as you begin to not trust a character and wait for this person's "just desserts," that character turns out to be a loving and trusted individual.
There are dozens of plot twists with each episode that keep me "glued to the tube."
I am currently near the end of Season Three and can't stop watching, raising hell with my bedtime schedule.  I don't see how they can keep it up (or how I can survive) through the remaining Seasons -- I believe there are at least five or more in all.  I would recommend this series to everyone -- it's a helluva ride!

intricate writing

Innovative, and intense, 24 was a groundbreaking series that drew watchers into a classic evil versus good scenario:  the potential reality of a well-funded and motivated terrorist cell striking at an American political figure versus the competent and honorable yet flawed/human U.S. counterterrorism system, embodied by Kiefer Sutherland's Jack Bauer.

What few may recall is that 24's debut was originally to be September 2001 but was pushed back to November in the aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist acts. Given the nation's raw emotional state when the series premiered, its straightforward get-the-job-done-by-any-means-possible approach, tempered by Bauer's personal & emotional entanglement in the premise, resonated deeply with American society and no doubt contributed to its initial popularity.

This is without question Sutherland's career-defining role, as it was for many of this and future seasons' cast members.

If you're looking for a spy show with contemporary issues and plenty of action, this is it. Keifer Southerland does a great job as Jack Bauer, former Special Forces operative who now works in a US government counterterrorist unit. Lots of other attractive people in the cast, mostly not that well known; Dennis Haysbert (The Unit, Allstate commercials) is also good as the US President. My main criticism is that the sensationalism used to "keep you hanging" from episode to episode detracts from the show, especially regarding Kim Bauer, Jack's daughter. The frequency with which she makes stupid decisions regardless of past experience is just unrealistic and maddening. But maybe I'm expecting too much......Overall, an entertaining show and worth watching given the paucity of good dramas available on television these days.

I just finished watching season 2014 and it was great so I started watching the earlier seasons staring with episode 1. It wasn't long before I realized that I tried this once before but I could not remember why I stopped watching the series. It was around episode 2 or 3 and it all came back but I said to myself - "Self...give it a chance, maybe you weren't ready for it back then."

Well I made to, or should I say struggled to, episode 20 and just could not take it anymore. I cannot fathom  how Jack's daughter gets kidnapped 3 times by THE SAME PEOPLE and at the same time his wife is, raped, kidnapped by different members of the same group and while escaping bangs her head and develops  temporary amnesia. Then Jack is taken hostage by the leader that hired the PEOPLE to kidnap his wife and daughter.

Meanwhile, throughout all of this Jack is trying to prevent an assassination attempt on a Senator who is running for president.

Now, these events do not happen all at once, they happen throughout episode 1 -20. Its like the writers never could figure out how to end a season.

So, if you are a huge 24 fan this may be for you. However, as hard as I tried the old series is not for me.

I'm into Season 2 now and so far haven't seen that. This season holds my attention more than the first. I think they have the right actors in the right parts. I look forward to each episode. I really enjoy the program.  However, it is too intense for my wife....she won't sit in the same room with me while it is on.  So I have to watch it when she is gone or on my Kindle.  Otherwise, for just me I would give it 5 stars.  I very much appreciate the "cleanness" of the program.  No filthy language.  No blatant coitus.  No promoting the homosexual agenda.  I am fine with violence.  Showing several scenes at once occasionally is real genius.  Kept me guessing who the government bad guys are.  The loud  "boing-boing-boing" between segments is sometimes annoying (I am thankful for the mute button).  Looking forward to future episodes.  I hope they don't degenerate in quality of content. If they do, I will discontinue watching "24".

I definitely enjoyed the series but felt at times it was a bit prolonged unnecessarily. I understand the layout or format and that it has two be stretched out over a 24 hour period but at the same time I wanted it to end.after his wife was kidnapped and finally reclaimed I was surprised that the main character did not supply his wife and daughter with weapons an attempt to train them to survive.his wife finally shot the man that raped her and was prepared to shoot anyone else for that matter in order to get free. I was intrigued by the secrets with and secrets with and secrets at the CTS installation.also that even in a intelligence office there is politicking and manipulation and control issues.actors chosen to play the villains were good but at the same time I fell for to have a real authentic flavor they should have picked up genuine actors that had the look and the accent of the country they were from.one possibility for the father figure villain would have been Jurgen Prochnow he has the kind of rough and gritty face that is perfect for villainy.also the main characters daughter after escaping from a potential rape and kidnap situation be thrown in with hardened criminals in a jail situation and then she impetuous lea decides to go back into a additional tense situation of a drug situation drug deal. I just felt it was a bit incredible that she could be that stupid.for the most part despite my criticisms I enjoy the series and will most likely go on to the additional seasons to see if they've made additional improvements on the character.because the situation is stretched out over the 24 hour period week after week it doesn't have the same visceral gutsy satisfaction the regular spy movie should have

 If you like to see constant horrible things happening to people, human life meaning absolutely nothing to some of the characters, too many of them, in fact, a lot of violence, betrayals, and traumatic events, almost no likeable, sympathetic characters,  and something with an unhappy ending this is for you. Season one of the 24 series is excellent.  A nice introduction to Jack Bauer as a regular guy who juggles a wife and kid with this high powered job as a field agent for C.T.U. and also acts as an administrator back at the office.  You just know that somethings got to give.  Eventually as always his first love, which is his job overwhelms everything else in his life.  It's kind of interesting that the first season hit the airwaves about a month after 9/11, and was so on time,as this show always seems to be.  The storyline is multi- layered, with maybe three stories going on at once, which is kind of alluded to by the split screen effect.  Then near the end of the season all the stories intertwine and become one story, which it always was.  The fact that 24 always shows that this stuff is complicated and there are many players involved, including sellouts on our side who go for the fast buck, is so true.  Nice series and very on time.
Loved this first season for far. :)

Hmmm, where to begin.  The premise of the show is innovative, particularly given the rise of both international terrorism as well as home grown terrorism.  The acting is not bad either.  The main issue with this season is the writing.  To paraphrase one reviewer, I only hope our own Dept of Homeland Security isn't this stupid.  For instance, season one featured seven kidnappings in one day.  Really, how stupid.  The plot line was unrealistic and just plain dumb.  The actors did what they could with what little they had to work with but, in the end, even good acting could not save this show.  How it lasted eight seasons is a testament to Hollywood not putting out quality dramas.  I tried to watch it but, in the end, had to quit watching with two episodes left.  It was just not believeable.

Probably should avoid this one.

Love Keifer Sutherland!  He is perfect for 24.  The action is paced to keep attention fixed and then..the episode is over!  I have watched three episodes so far..the rest of the cast does such a good job...though something does not ring right about Jack's wife.  Good actress but chemistry does not seem on target.  There are about 197 episodes to go..and I plan to enjoy them..!
Loved it!
Great!

awesome. can't wait to see season 2  was easy to watch on my smart tv  action filled exciting can't wait to watch it every day

Can't understand why I didn't start watching this a long time ago.  Watching Breaking Bad only years after it started convinced me there was a lot of great acting, scripts and cinematography that I wasn't aware of.  This is another example.

Love everything about the program.  However, I would not recommend it for children. Lots of violence.

"24" has become one of my favorite TV shows, but one reason that Season 1 stands out still is because it is not quite as over-the-top as some of the subsequent seasons, so the lengths that Jack Bauer will go to for his wife and daughter make it more believable than trying to save an abstract number of people from an unfathomable terror. Excellent!

Binge worthy! Great show to watch, you will not want to wait for the next episode so be warned! you may not be able to turn it off!
glad to see Jack Bauer-  enjoy the action! good supporting family drama included with "future" prez.  smart and intriguing, makes it good for some conversation.

The suspense builds from the beginning, with its twists and turns. Excellent acting. Will keep you glued to your TV,

Excellent!  I am retiring very late since I am so caught up in this show that I find it hard to wait for the next edition.

Great show...suspenseful and keep you wanting to watch the next episode. ..i think I am going to watch all the seasons.
Can't stop watching this.  So many twists and turns in the plot and character.  I didn't see things coming in the plot.
I just cant stop watching. It keeps my complete attention, Jack Bauer is a good bad boy. Our country probably needs a person like this for real

24 is not as well acted as Orphan Black, Sherlock, or even Doctor Who.  The story lines are more like General Hospital than a cable channel drama.  That said there is something very compelling about watch 24 hours in anyone's life - especially the head of a special terrorist unit agent who is unstoppable.  I am taking a break before watching season 2.
Kept me on the edge of my seat as I "binge watched" Season #1.  Looking forward to watching future Seasons.
The story had great twists and turns and was constantly moving. There were cliff hangers within the episodes. Couldn't stop until we'd finished the season.
It seems that Jack and his family can't catch a break!  If I had their luck, I'd stay in bed! LOL

Great action series. The one thing that does bother me is how Jack's daughter Kim is
a total trouble magnet.

This is a brilliant show. It engages you and it will be rather hard for you to only watch one episode. It's fast-paced. You don't get bored.
If this had been a book I would call it a "page turner" - I couldn't stop watching it. Especially since they leave you in suspense in the final minutes of each episode! Great series.
Great series, good picture quality.  Totally satisfied. Look forward to the rest of the series in the future.  This is soooo! cool.
Good acting and story line. Great for binge watching, Can't believe we didn't watch it when it was originally broadcast.
